On 29 November 2011 21:29, Wesley Tansey <tansey@...> wrote:
>
>
> Regarding your last question, SharpNEAT implements network activation using a fixed number of iterations, and it's actually quite
> fast. There is a precision trade off to consider, however, since you will need to guess the depth of what a good network may look
> like. I'm sure Colin could speak more to this design decision as well as your other questions.

Hi, FTYI the latest version (2.1) allows for evolving of acyclic
networks. So I basically do a little more work when performing
mutations in order to avoid cyclic nets. Then at activation time there
is an acyclic network class that propagates input signals through the
net layer by layer - so it's more efficient than the old approach of
guessing the appropriate depth and activating the net that number of
times.

In fact there is a class that performs depth analysis on both cyclic
and acyclic nets, it was originally written for the acyclic nets only
but as I was writing it I realised that it only required a small tweak
to make it work for cylic nets. This then got used to improve the
layout of nodes in the network visualization window - but I didn't
update the cyclic network /activation/ to use it, but that's also a
possibility now I think of it.

Hope that helps a bit.

Colin
